newsitem.title: ITALY: ALPINE SKIING-TOMBA RETURNS TO ITALIAN ADULATION.
newsitem.headline: ALPINE SKIING-TOMBA RETURNS TO ITALIAN ADULATION.

text.p: Alberto Tomba finally returned to the Alpine skiing circuit on Tuesday and rewarded his loud and exuberant fans with the eighth fastest time in the first leg of a World Cup slalom.

Austrian Siegfried Voglreiter, who has never finished a slalom higher than sixth place, was well positioned for a remarkable first win after starting 23rd and clocking the fastest unofficial time of 46.40 seconds.
Norway's Ole Christian Furuseth, starting 13th, clocked 45.54 but admitted that he had missed a gate and was disqualified.

France's Sebastien Amiez, who was lucky to escape unhurt from a heavy crash in Tuesday's warm-up, was equal second fastest with Austrian Thomas Sykora over the 55-gate first leg on Madonna's Canalone Miramonti piste in 46.47.
While the Austrians again found themselves leading the field, there was no doubt who was the star on a sunny day with Italians out in force to see their hero return.

Tomba, who celebrates his 30th birthday on Thursday and is sporting a longer, curly hairstyle having left the Carabinieri paramilitary police, started for the first time this season after being sidelined by a knee and wrist injury.

Suitably, for the world slalom champion, Tomba had bib number one and was first out of the starting hut to a cacophany of klaxons from a loyal fan club finally given their first chance of the season to let loose all their energies.
"With Alberto on the piste, its a big party," read a banner at the finish. "Welcome back, Alberto" said another.
"He needs a few races," said Furuseth, adding that it was "very good" to see the Italian back again.
Tomba, who clocked a competitive 47.13 seconds, said the piste was not as good as it had been last year -- when he won on his birthday -- but he was pleased with his performance.
He was followed down by Austria's Michael Tritscher, who crashed heavily half way down the piste.
The Austrian, currently fifth in the slalom World Cup standings, lay on the snow while medical staff attended to him. He later reappeared at the finish, limping.
Tritscher said he had fallen when his right knee suddenly gave way and he would be having further checks.
Compatriot Thomas Stangassinger, second in the slalom standings after a second and a third place this season, also fell just a couple of gates from the finish.
The second, 62-gate leg was due to start at 1200 GMT
